A '''planet symbol''' (or ''planetary symbol'') is a graphical symbol used in [[astrological symbol|astrology]] and [[astronomical symbol|astronomy]] to represent a [[classical planet]] (including the Sun and the Moon) or one of the eight modern planets. The symbols are also used in [[alchemy]] to represent the metals that are [[Classical planets in Western alchemy|associated]] with the planets. The use of these symbols is based in ancient [[Greco-Roman astronomy]], although their current shapes are a development of the 16th century.
The classical planets with their symbols and associated metals are: <center> {| class=wikitable |- |planet || Moon || Mercury || Venus || Sun || Mars || Jupiter || Saturn |- |symbol || {{resize|150%|☾}} || {{resize|150%|☿}} || {{resize|150%|♀}} || {{resize|150%|☉}} || {{resize|150%|♂}} || {{resize|150%|♃}} || {{resize|150%|♄}} |- |metal || silver || mercury || copper || gold || iron || tin || lead |- |} </center>
The [[International Astronomical Union]] discourages the use of these symbols in modern journal articles, and their style manual proposes one- and two-letter abbreviations for the names of the planets for cases where planetary symbols might be used, such as in the headings of tables.<ref name=iau-style-manual >{{cite book | title = The IAU Style Manual | url = http://www.iau.org/static/publications/stylemanual1989.pdf | date = 1989 | page = 27 }}</ref> The modern planets with their symbols and abbreviations recommended by the IAU: <center> {| class=wikitable |- |planet || Mercury || Venus || Earth || Mars || Jupiter ||Saturn || Uranus || Neptune |- |symbol || {{resize|150%|☿}} || {{resize|150%|♀}} || {{resize|150%|♁}} || {{resize|150%|♂}} || {{resize|150%|♃}} || {{resize|150%|♄}} || {{resize|150%|⛢}} || {{resize|150%|♆}} |- |IAU || Me || V || E || Ma || J || S || U || N |- |} </center>
The symbols of Venus and Mars are also used to represent [[female]] and [[male]] in biology and botany, following a convention introduced by [[Linnaeus]] in the 1750s.
==History== ===Classical planets=== The written symbols for Mercury, Venus, Jupiter, and Saturn have been traced to forms found in late Greek papyri.<ref name=jones-1999>{{cite book | title = Astronomical papyri from Oxyrhynchus | last = Jones | first = Alexander | date = 1999 | pages = 62–63 | isbn = 0-87169-233-3 }}</ref> Early forms are also found in medieval Byzantine codices which preserve ancient horoscopes.<ref name=neugebauer-1975>{{cite book | title = A history of ancient mathematical astronomy | last = Neugebauer | first = Otto | date = 1975 | pages = 788–789 | isbn = 0-387-06995-X }}</ref> Antecedents of the planetary symbols are attested in the attributes given to classical deities, represented in simplified pictographic form in the Roman era. ''Bianchini's [[planisphere]]'' (2nd century, [[Louvre]] inv. Ma 540)<ref name=imss>{{cite web | url = http://brunelleschi.imss.fi.it/galileopalazzostrozzi/object/BianchinisPlanisphere.html | title = Bianchini's planisphere | publisher = Istituto e Museo di Storia della Scienza (Institute and Museum of the History of Science) | location = Florence, Italy | accessdate = 2010-03-17 }}</ref> shows the seven planets represented by portraits of the seven corresponding gods, each with a simple representation of an attribute, as follows: Mercury has a [[caduceus]]; Venus has a cord attached to her necklace which is connected to another necklace; Mars has a spear; Jupiter has a staff; Saturn has a scythe; the Sun has a circlet with rays emanating from it; and the Moon has a headdress with a crescent attached.<ref name=maunder>Maunder (1934)</ref>
A diagram in the astronomical compendium by Johannes Kamateros (12th century) shows the Sun represented by the circle with a ray, Jupiter by the letter ''zeta'' (the initial of [[Zeus]], Jupiter's counterpart in Greek mythology), Mars by a shield crossed by a spear, and the remaining classical planets by symbols resembling the modern ones, without the cross-mark seen in modern versions of the symbols. These cross-marks first appear in the late 15th or early 16th century. According to Maunder, the addition of crosses appears to be "an attempt to give a savour of Christianity to the symbols of the old pagan gods."<ref name=maunder />
The modern symbols for the seven classical planets are found in a woodcut of the seven planets in a Latin translation of [[Abu Ma'shar]]'s ''De Magnis Coniunctionibus'' printed at Venice in 1506, represented as the corresponding gods riding chariots.<ref name=maunder239>Maunder (1934:239)</ref> <gallery> File:Fotothek df tg 0007129 Theosophie ^ Alchemie.jpg|Early modern depiction of the planet symbols in an alchemical context (''[[Musaeum Hermeticum]]'', 1678) File:Translation of Albumasar Venice 1515 De Magnis Coniunctionibus.jpg|Page spread (with the signs for Mars and Venus) from a 1515 illustrated edition of [[Abu Ma'shar]]'s ''De Magnis Coniunctionibus'' (in the by translation by [[Herman of Carinthia]], c. 1140, ''editio princeps'' by Erhard Ratdolt of Augsburg, 1489). Abu Ma'shar(Ibn Balkhi)-850AD.png|Depiction of the planets in a 15th-century Arabic manuscript of Abu Ma'shar's "Book of nativities"<ref>BNF Arabe 2583 fol. 15v. Saturn is shown as a black bearded man, kneeling and holding a scythe or axe; Mercury is shown as a scribe holding an open codex; Jupiter as a man of the law wearing a turban; Venus as a lute-player; Mars as a helmeted warrior holding a sword and the head of an enemy.</ref> File:F4.v. zodiac circle with planets - NLW MS 735C.png|Medieval [[planisphere]] showing the [[zodiac]] and the [[classical planets]]. The planets are represented by seven faces. </gallery>
===Earth symbol=== {{main|Earth symbol}} {{multiple image | width1 = 150 | image1 = Earth symbol A.svg | width2 = 95 | image2 = Earth symbol alternate.svg | footer = }} {{commons category|Earth symbols}} [[Earth]] is not one of the classical planets (the word "planet" by definition describing "wandering stars" as seen from Earth's surface). Its status as planet is a consequence of the development of [[heliocentrism]]. Nevertheless, there are ancient symbols for Earth, notably a [[cross]] representing the four [[cardinal direction]]s, as a cross in a circle also interpreted as a globe with [[equator]] and a [[meridian (geography)|meridian]];<ref name=penny-cyclopaedia>{{cite book | title = The Penny cyclopædia of the Society for the Diffusion of Useful Knowledge | volume = 22 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=rJhOFg1yiqUC&pg=PA197 | publisher = C. Knight | date = 1842 | page = 197 }}</ref><ref name=encyclopedia-americana>{{cite book | title = The Encyclopedia Americana: a library of universal knowledge | volume = 26 | publisher = Encyclopedia Americana Corp. | date = 1920 | pages = 162–163 | url = https://archive.org/stream/encyclopediaame01unkngoog#page/n202/mode/2up | accessdate = 2011-03-24 }}</ref> The "Earth" symbol is encoded by Unicode at U+1F728 ({{resize|150%|🜨}}; alternative characters with similar shape are: U+2295 ⊕ CIRCLED PLUS; U+2A01 ⨁ N-ARY CIRCLED PLUS OPERATOR). Alternatively, there is the [[globus cruciger]] [[File:Earth symbol alternate.svg|16x25px|Earth]] (U+2641 {{resize|150%|♁}}), now most commonly used as planetary symbol. The "globus cruciger" symbol is also used as an alchemical symbol of [[antimony]]. {{clear}}
===Modern discoveries=== [[File:Bezeichnung der Himmelskörper Encke 1850.png|thumb|upright=0.75|“Designation of celestial bodies” in a German almanac printed 1850<ref name=Encke>[[Johann Franz Encke]], ''Berliner Astronomisches Jahrbuch für 1853'', Berlin 1850, p. VIII</ref>]]
[[Uranus]] [[File:Uranus symbol.svg|x25px|Uranus]] (U+26E2 {{resize|150%|⛢}}), also [[File:Uranus's astrological symbol.svg|x25px|Uranus]] U+2645 {{resize|150%|♅}}, a globe surmounted by the letter ''H'' for [[Sir William Herschel|Herschel]]): The symbols for [[Uranus]] were created shortly after its discovery in 1781. One symbol, [[File:Uranus symbol.svg|15px|Uranus]], invented by [[Johann Gottfried Koehler|J. G. Köhler]] and refined by [[Johann Elert Bode|Bode]], was intended to represent the newly discovered metal [[platinum]]; since platinum, commonly called white gold, was found by chemists mixed with iron, the symbol for platinum combines the alchemical symbols for [[iron]], ♂, and [[gold]], ☉.<ref name=bode-uranus>{{cite book | title = Von dem neu entdeckten Planeten | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=ZqA5AAAAcAAJ&pg=PA95 | last = Bode | first = J. E. | date = 1784 | pages = 95–96 }}</ref><ref name=gould-uranus>{{cite book | title = Report on the history of the discovery of Neptune | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=uyANAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA5 | last = Gould | first = B. A. | publisher = Smithsonian Institution | date = 1850 | page = 5 }}</ref> This symbol also combines the symbols of Mars (♂) and the Sun (☉) because in Greek Mythology, Uranus represented heaven, and represents the combined power of Mars' spear and the Sun.<ref name=Cain>{{cite web|last=Cain|first=Fraser|title=Symbol for Uranus|url=http://www.universetoday.com/19126/symbol-for-uranus/|work=Universe Today|accessdate=18 March 2013}}</ref> Another symbol, [[File:Uranus's astrological symbol.svg|15px|Uranus]], was suggested by Lalande in 1784. In a letter to Herschel, Lalande described it as "un globe surmonté par la première lettre de votre nom" ("a globe surmounted by the first letter of your name").<ref name=Francisca>{{Cite journal |title=The meaning of the symbol H+o for the planet Uranus |url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-data_query?bibcode=1917Obs....40..306H&link_type=ARTICLE&db_key=AST&high= |author=Francisca Herschel|date=August 1917|work=The Observatory |bibcode=1917Obs....40..306H}}</ref>
[[Neptune]] [[File:Neptune symbol.svg|x25px|Neptune]] (U+2646 {{resize|150%|♆}}), [[Neptune (mythology)|Neptune's]] [[trident]], also [[File:Neptune symbol alternate.svg|x25px|Neptune (alternate symbol)]], a globe surmounted by the letters "L" and "V" for [[Le Verrier]]):<ref name=an-25>{{cite journal | last = Schumacher | first = H. C. | date = 1846 | title = Name des Neuen Planeten | journal = Astronomische Nachrichten | volume = 25 | pages = 81–82 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=wlc_AAAAcAAJ&pg=PA89 | bibcode = 1846AN.....25...81L |doi = 10.1002/asna.18470250603 }}</ref> Several symbols were proposed for [[Neptune]] to accompany the suggested names for the planet. Claiming the right to name his discovery, [[Urbain Le Verrier]] originally proposed the name ''Neptune''<ref name="littmann-standish"> {{cite book | first=Mark |last=Littmann |author2=Standish, E. M. | title=Planets Beyond: Discovering the Outer Solar System | date=2004 |page=50 | publisher=Courier Dover Publications |isbn=0-486-43602-0 }}</ref> and the symbol of a [[trident]],<ref name="pillans">{{cite journal | last = Pillans | first = James | title = Ueber den Namen des neuen Planeten | journal = Astronomische Nachrichten | volume = 25 | issue = 26 | pages = 389–392 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=yOAzAQAAIAAJ&pg=RA1-PA39-IA11 | date= 1847 | doi = 10.1002/asna.18470252602 | bibcode=1847AN.....25..389. }}</ref> while falsely stating that this had been officially approved by the French [[Bureau des Longitudes]].<ref name="littmann-standish" /> In October, he sought to name the planet ''Leverrier'', after himself, and he had loyal support in this from the observatory director, [[François Arago]],<ref name="baum-sheehan"> {{cite book | last=Baum|first=Richard|last2=Sheehan|first2=William | date=2003|pages=109–110 | title=In Search of Planet Vulcan: The Ghost in Newton's Clockwork Universe | publisher=Basic Books |isbn=0-7382-0889-2 }}</ref> who in turn proposed a new symbol for the planet ([[File:Neptune symbol alternate.svg|x15px|proposed symbol for planet Leverrier]]).<ref name=an-25 /> However, this suggestion met with stiff resistance outside [[France]].<ref name="baum-sheehan" /> French almanacs quickly reintroduced the name ''Herschel'' for ''Uranus'', after that planet's discoverer Sir [[William Herschel]], and ''Leverrier'' for the new planet.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Gingerich|first=Owen|date=October 1958|title=The Naming of Uranus and Neptune|url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/full/1958ASPL....8....9G|dead-url=no|journal=Astronomical Society of the Pacific Leaflets|volume=8|pages=9–15|bibcode=1958ASPL....8....9G|archive-url=http://www.webcitation.org/71hwNHcs4|archive-date=2018-08-16|via=NASA Astrophysics Data System}}</ref> Professor [[James Pillans]] of the [[University of Edinburgh]] defended the name ''[[Janus]]'' for the new planet, and proposed a key for its symbol.<ref name="pillans" /> Meanwhile, [[Friedrich Georg Wilhelm von Struve|Struve]]<!--- (1793–1864), or maybe his son Otto Wilhelm von Struve (1819–1905) ---> presented the name ''Neptune'' on December 29, 1846, to the [[Russian Academy of Sciences|Saint Petersburg Academy of Sciences]].<ref>{{cite journal |title=Second report of proceedings in the Cambridge Observatory relating to the new Planet (Neptune) |date=1847 |journal=Astronomische Nachrichten |volume=25 |issue=21 |pages=309–314 |last=Hind|first=J. R. |doi=10.1002/asna.18470252102 |bibcode = 1847AN.....25..309. }}</ref> In August 1847, the Bureau des Longitudes announced its decision to follow prevailing astronomical practice and adopt the choice of ''Neptune'', with Arago refraining from participating in this decision.<ref name="connaissance-des-temps">{{cite book | title = Connaissance des temps: ou des mouvementes célestes, à l'usage des astronomes | date = 1847 | page = unnumbered front matter | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=5q03AAAAMAAJ&pg=PP9 | author1 = Bureau Des Longitudes, France }}</ref>
[[Pluto]] was also considered a planet from its discovery in 1930 until its re-classification as a "[[dwarf planet]]" in 2006. The symbol used for Pluto was a ligature of the letters P and L (Unicode U+2647 {{resize|150%|♇}}).
In the 19th century, symbols for the major [[asteroid]]s were also in use, including [[4 Vesta|Vesta]] (an altar with fire on it; {{resize|150%|⚶}} U+26B6), [[3 Juno|Juno]] (a sceptre; {{resize|150%|⚵}} U+26B5), [[Ceres (dwarf planet)|Ceres]] (a reaper's scythe; {{resize|150%|⚳}} U+26B3),<ref name=penny-cyclopaedia /> [[2 Pallas|Pallas]] ({{resize|150%|⚴}} U+26B4); Encke (1850) has further symbols for [[5 Astraea|Astraea]], [[6 Hebe|Hebe]], [[7 Iris|Iris]], [[8 Flora|Flora]] and [[9 Metis|Metis]].<ref name=Encke/> Unicode furthermore has a symbol ({{resize|150%|⚷}} U+26B7) for [[2060 Chiron]] (discovered 1977).
==Classical planets== {{see|Classical planets|Days of the week}}
===Moon=== {{see|Crescent|Astronomical symbols#Symbols for the Sun and Moon}} [[File:Moon symbol decrescent.svg|thumb|150px]] {{commonscat|Luna symbols}} {{commonscat|Crescent moon symbols}} The [[crescent]] shape has been used to represent the Moon since earliest times. In classical anqituity, it is worn by lunar deities ([[Selene|Selene/Luna]], [[Artemis|Artemis/Diana]], [[Men (deity)|Men]], etc.) either on the head or behind the shoulders, with its horns pointing upward. Its representation with the horns pointing sideways (as a heraldic ''crescent increscent'' or ''crescent decrescent'') is early modern.
The same symbol can be used in a different context not for the Moon itself but for a [[lunar phase]], as part of a sequence of four symbols for "new moon" (U+1F311 🌑), "waxing" (U+263D ☽), "full moon" (U+1F315 🌕) and "waning" (U+263E ☾).
{{clear}}
===Mercury=== [[File:Mercury symbol.svg|thumb|150px]] {{commonscat|Mercury symbols}}
The symbol [[File:Mercury symbol.svg|x25px|Mercury]] for [[Mercury (planet)|Mercury]](U+263F {{resize|150%|☿}}) is ultimately derived from the [[caduceus]], or intertwined serpents, which were the main attribute of [[Mercury (mythology)|Mercury/Hermes]] throughout antiquity.<ref name=cox>{{cite book | last = Cox | first = Arthur | title = Allen's astrophysical quantities | publisher = Springer | date = 2001 | page = 2 | isbn = 0-387-95189-X }}</ref><ref name=high-school-astronomy>{{cite book | last = Mattison | first = Hiram | title = High-School Astronomy | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=XksAAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA32 | publisher = Sheldon & Co. | date = 1872 | pages = 32–36 }}</ref><ref name=penny-cyclopaedia /> The caduceus was usually shown with at least three loops, but this was simplified to a single loop in the diagram of Kamateros (12th century).<ref name=maunder/> The modern symbol has also been interpreted as representing the god's [[Petasos|winged headdress]].<ref>"staff and winged helmet of Mercury" Tim Collins, ''Behind the Lost Symbol'' (2010), [https://books.google.com/books?id=L-oCD0fVspkC&pg=PT128 p. 128]<!--Dan-Brown-cruft, probably the "winged helmet" is just 'citogenesis' lifted off Wikipedia. https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Astronomical_symbols&oldid=327900095 --> </ref>
<gallery> File:Wappen Stahlberg.png|Mercury symbol, representing mercury (quicksilver) mining, in the municipal coat of arms of [[Stahlberg]], [[Rhineland-Palatinate]], Germany. </gallery> {{clear}}
===Venus=== [[File:Venus symbol.svg|thumb|150px]] {{commons category|Venus symbols}} The '''Venus symbol''' (♀) consists of a circle with a small [[Cross (symbol)|cross]] below it. It originates in [[Late Antiquity]] as an [[astrological symbol]] for the [[classical planet|planet]] [[Venus]] (associated with the [[Venus (mythology)|goddess Venus]]), and hence as [[alchemy|alchemical]] symbol for [[copper]]. In modern times, it is still used as the [[astronomical symbol]] for Venus, although its use is discouraged by the [[International Astronomical Union]].<ref name=iau-style-manual >{{cite book | title = The IAU Style Manual | url = http://www.iau.org/static/publications/stylemanual1989.pdf | date = 1989 | page = 27 }}</ref>
In [[zoology]] and [[botany]], it is used to represent the female sex (alongside the astrological symbol for [[Mars]] representing the male sex), following a convention introduced by [[Linnaeus]] in the 1750s.<ref name="Stearn">{{cite journal|last=Stearn|first=William T.|title=The Origin of the Male and Female Symbols of Biology|journal=Taxon|date=May 1962|volume=11|issue=4|pages=109–113|jstor=1217734|doi=10.2307/1217734}} "In his Systema Naturae (Leyden, 1735) he [Linnaeus] used them with their traditional associations for metals. Their first biological use is in the Linnaean dissertation ''Plantae hybridae xxx sistit J. J. Haartman'' (1751) where in discussing hybrid plants Linnaeus denoted the supposed female parent species by the sign ♀, the male parent by the sign ♂, the hybrid by ☿ 'matrem signo ♀, patrem ♂ & plantam hybridam ☿ designavero'. In subsequent publications he retained the signs ♀ and ♂ for male and female individuals but discarded ☿ for hybrids; the last are now indicated by the multiplication sign ×. Linnaeus's first general use of the signs of ♀ and ♂ was in his ''Species Plantarum'' (1753) written between 1746 and 1752 and surveying concisely the whole plant kingdom as then known." (p. 110)</ref> Following the biological convention, the symbol in the 20th century{{year needed|date=September 2016}} also came to be used in sociological contexts to represent [[women]] or [[femininity]].
The symbol appears without the cross-mark (⚲) in Johannes Kamateros (12th century). In the ''Bianchini's planisphere'' (2nd century), Venus is represented by a necklace.<ref name=imss/> The idea that the symbol represents the goddess' [[hand mirror]] dates to the 19th century.<ref>see Hiram Mattison, ''A high-school astronomy'' (1857), [https://books.google.com/books?id=HocEAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA32 p. 32].</ref>
[[Unicode]] encodes the FEMALE SIGN at U+2640 (♀), in the [[Miscellaneous Symbols]] block.<ref>In the official [https://www.unicode.org/charts/PDF/U2600.pdf code chart] glossed " = Venus = alchemical symbol for copper → 1F469 [[👩]] woman → 1F6BA [[🚺]] womens symbol".</ref>
<gallery> File:Neuter symbol.svg| Medieval (Johannes Kamateros, 12th century) form of the Venus symbol; the horizontal stroke was added to form a [[Christian cross]] in the early modern period.<ref name=maunder245>Maunder (1934), p. 245.</ref> File:Falun vapen.svg| The Venus symbol in the municipal coat of arms of [[Falun Municipality]] in Sweden (1932), here representing copper mining.<ref>Falun was the site of a copper mine from at least the 13th century. A coat of arms including a copper sign is recorded for 1642; the current design dates to the early 20th century, and was given official recognition in 1932. It was slightly simplified upon the formation of the modern municipality in 1971 (registered with the [[Swedish Patent and Registration Office]]. in 1988).</ref> Image:Woman-power emblem.svg |[[Raised fist]] within Venus symbol, used as a symbol of [[second-wave feminism]] (1960s)<ref>Claimed to have been designed by [[Robin Morgan]] in the 1960s. "Morgan designed the universal logo of the women’s movement, the woman’s symbol centered with a raised fist" ([http://www.robinmorgan.net/activism/ robinmorgan.net])</ref> </gallery>
===Sun=== {{see|Solar symbol|Astronomical_symbols#Symbols_for_the_Sun_and_Moon|label2=Symbols for the Sun and Moon}} [[File:Sun symbol.svg|thumb|150px]] {{commons category|Sun symbols}} The modern astronomical symbol for the Sun ([[circled dot]], Unicode U+2609 ☉) was first used in the Renaissance.
''Bianchini's [[planisphere]]'', produced in the 2nd century, has a [[circlet]] with rays radiating from it.<ref name=maunder/><ref name=imss>{{cite web | url = http://brunelleschi.imss.fi.it/galileopalazzostrozzi/object/BianchinisPlanisphere.html | title = Bianchini's planisphere | publisher = Istituto e Museo di Storia della Scienza (Institute and Museum of the History of Science) | location = Florence, Italy | accessdate = 2010-03-17 }}</ref> A diagram in Johannes Kamateros' 12th century ''Compendium of Astrology'' shows the Sun represented by a circle with a ray.<ref name=neugebauer-1987>{{cite book | title = Greek Horoscopes | last1 = Neugebauer | first1 = Otto | last2 = Van Hoesen | first2 = H. B. | date = 1987 | pages = 1, 159, 163 }}</ref> This older symbol is encoded by [[Unicode]] (version 9.0, June 2016) as "ALCHEMICAL SYMBOL FOR GOLD" (🜚 U+1F71A) in the [[Alchemical Symbols (Unicode)|Alchemical Symbols]] block.
<gallery> File:Old symbol for sun.svg| Medieval (Johannes Kamateros, 12th century)<ref name=maunder245/> astronomical symbol for the Sun (and alchemical symbol for gold) </gallery> {{clear}}
===Mars=== [[Image:Mars symbol.svg|150px|thumb]] {{commons category|Mars symbols}} The '''Mars symbol''' (♂) is a depiction of a circle with an arrow emerging from it, pointing at an angle to the upper right. As astrological symbol it represents the planet [[Mars]] (connected to the [[Mars (deity)|god Mars (Ares)]]) and hence iron in alchemy. In zoology and botany, it is used to represent the male sex (alongside the astrological symbol for Venus representing the female sex), following a convention introduced by [[Linnaeus]] in the 1750s.<ref name="Stearn"/>
The symbol in its current form represents spear and shield and dates to the early 16th century. It is derived from a medieval form where the spear was drawn across the shield, which in turn was based on a convention used in antiquity (''Bianchini's planisphere'') which represented Mars by a spear.<ref name=imss>{{cite web | url = http://brunelleschi.imss.fi.it/galileopalazzostrozzi/object/BianchinisPlanisphere.html | title = Bianchini's planisphere | publisher = Istituto e Museo di Storia della Scienza (Institute and Museum of the History of Science) | location = Florence, Italy | accessdate = 2010-03-17 }}</ref> A diagram in the 12th-century ''Compendium of Astrology'' by Johannes Kamateros represents Mars by a shield crossed by a spear.<ref name=neugebauer-1987/>
<gallery>File:Karlskoga vapen.svg| The Mars symbol (representing [[Ironworks|iron mining]]) in the municipal coat of arms of [[Karlskoga]] in Sweden</gallery>
===Jupiter=== [[File:Jupiter symbol.svg|thumb|150px]] {{commons category|Jupiter symbols}} The origin of the symbol for [[Jupiter]] [[File:Jupiter symbol.svg|x25px|Jupiter]] (U+2643 {{resize|150%|♃}}) is not entirely clear. [[Jupiter (mythology)|Jupiter]]'s attribute is a sceptre (as [[king of the gods]]), but Kamateros (12th century) represents Jupiter simply by the letter ''[[zeta]]'' ζ (for ''[[Zeus]]''). The modern symbol as used from the 16th century is apparently based on a majuscule zeta Ζ with the addition of a vertical stroke to form the Christian cross.<ref name=maunder244>Maunder (1934), p. 244.</ref> The less-than-intuitive symbol gave rise to various ad hoc interpretations by modern commentators; thus, the editors of the ''Penny cyclopedia'' (1842) thought might "supposed to be a symbol of the thunder (arm and hand holding thunder?)"<ref name=penny-cyclopaedia/> and more recently the sign has been reported as based on the "Egyptian hieroglyph for the eagle".<ref>Pat Ward, Barbara Ward, ''Space Frontiers, Grades 4 - 8: EXPLORING Astronomy'', Carson-Dellosa Publishing, 22 Oct 2012 [https://books.google.com/books?id=I0zbfXcwTQ8C&pg=PA42 p. 42] (without further reference).<!--yeah, they took this from Wikipedia, where it was based on a 2008 web page from NASA https://web.archive.org/web/20100317223147/http://solarsystem.nasa.gov/multimedia/display.cfm?IM_ID=167 there doesn't seem to be a real reference for this, but it's made it into print now anyway. There is no Egyptian "eagle" hieroglyph, unless you count G1 (Egyptian vulture) which looks like -- an actual vulture/eagle. --> </ref>
{{clear}}
===Saturn=== [[File:Saturn symbol.svg|thumb|150px]] {{commons category|Saturn symbols}} [[Saturn (mythology)|Saturn]] is usually depicted with a [[scythe]] or [[sickle]], and the planetary symbol has apparently evolved from a picture of this attribute, in Kamateros (12th century) shown in a shape similar to the letter ''[[eta]]'' η, with the horizontal stroke added along with the "Christianization" of the other symbols in the early 16th century, [[File:Saturn symbol.svg|x25px|Saturn]] (U+2644 {{resize|150%|♄}}).
<gallery> File:FraternitasSaturniSiegel.svg|Emblem of the ''[[Fraternitas Saturni]]'', a German [[magical order]] founded in 1926. File:Wappen der Ortschaft Bleiwäsche.png|The Saturn symbol representing [[lead]] in the municipal coat of arms of ''Bleiwäsche'', since 1975 part of [[Bad Wünnenberg]], [[North Rhine-Westphalia]], Germany. </gallery>
{{clear}}
==Minor planets== ;Pluto [[File:Pluto symbol.svg|thumb|50px]] {{commons category|Pluto symbols}} The Unicode symbol for [[Pluto]] is (♇) PLUTO at U+2647.<ref name = officialchart>In the official [https://www.unicode.org/charts/PDF/U2600.pdf code chart].</ref>
{{clear}} ;Ceres [[File:Ceres symbol.svg|thumb|50px]] {{commons category|Ceres symbols}} The Unicode symbol for [[Ceres (dwarf planet)|Ceres]] is (⚳) CERES at U+26B3.<ref name = officialchart />
{{clear}}
;Pallas [[File:Pallas symbol.svg|thumb|50px]] {{commons category|(2) Pallas symbols}} The Unicode symbol for [[2 Pallas|Pallas]] is (⚴) PALLAS at U+26B4.<ref name = officialchart />
{{clear}}
;Juno [[File:Juno symbol.svg|thumb|50px]] {{commons category|(3) Juno symbols}} The Unicode symbol for [[3 Juno|Juno]] is (⚵) JUNO at U+26B5.<ref name = officialchart />
{{clear}}
;Vesta [[File:Vesta symbol.svg|thumb|50px]] {{commons category|Vesta (asteroid) symbol}} The Unicode for [[4 Vesta|Vesta]] is (⚶) VESTA at U+26B6.<ref name = officialchart />
{{clear}}
;Chiron [[File:Chiron symbol.svg|thumb|40px]] {{commons category|(2060) Chiron symbols}} The Unicode symbol for [[2060 Chiron|Chiron]] is (⚷) CHIRON at U+26B7.<ref name = officialchart />
{{clear}}
==See also== {{commons category|Planet symbols}} {{commons category|Alchemical symbols}} *[[Astrological symbol]] *[[Astronomical symbol]] *[[Gender symbol]] *[[Classical planets in Western alchemy]]

page.title: Power-control theory of gender and delinquency

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.5)
revision.text:
{{essay|date=January 2016}}
In [[criminology]], the '''power-control theory of gender and delinquency''' (abbreviated as the '''power-control theory''') holds the gender distribution of [[:wikt:delinquency|delinquency]] is caused by stratification from [[gender role|gender relations]] within the [[family]].<ref name="MessnerKrohn1989">{{Cite book|author1=Steven F. Messner|author2=Marvin D. Krohn|author3=Allen E. Liska|title=Theoretical integration in the study of deviance and crime: problems and propects|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U0lS-wWM-BAC|accessdate=19 March 2010|date=August 1989|publisher=SUNY Press|isbn=978-0-7914-0000-5|page=213}}</ref> The [[social theory|theory]] seeks to explain [[gender]] differences in the rates of delinquency by attributing them to the level of social/parental control practiced. The theory states that the [[social class|class]], [[gender]], and type of family structure (e.g. [[egalitarian]] or [[patriarchal]]) will influence the severity of social/parental control practiced which will in turn set the "accepted norm" for the child/individual.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.soc.umn.edu/~uggen/4141lec18.pdf|title=41481lec18|date=2008-04-03|work=Powerpoint notes|pages=2|accessdate=19 March 2010}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=J. Palumbo|first=Dennis |date=July 1997|title=CRIMINOLOGICAL CONTROVERSIES: A METHODOLOGICAL PRIMER|journal=Law and Politics Review|publisher=Department of Government & Politics, University of Maryland|volume= 7|issue= 7|pages=335–337|issn=1062-7421|url=http://www.bsos.umd.edu/gvpt/lpbr/subpages/reviews/HaganJ.htm}}</ref><ref name="Siegel2003">{{Cite book|author=Larry J. Siegel|title=Criminology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TQpNNH3O_OQC|accessdate=19 March 2010|year=2003|publisher=Wadsworth/Thomson Learning|isbn=978-0-534-52654-2|page=269}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=A. Bates|first=Kristin |author2=Christopher D. Bader |author3=F. Carson Mencken |year=2003|title=Family Structure, Power-Control Theory, and Deviance: Extending Power-control Theory to Include Alternate Family Forms|journal=Western Criminology Review|volume=4|issue=3|pages=170–190|issn=1096-4886|url=http://wcr.sonoma.edu/v4n3/Manuscripts/bates.pdf}}</ref> This norm will in turn control the level of delinquency by the individual.
Power-control theory differs from other control theories that view crime as a cause of low [[social status]] (cited from book). This theory compares gender and parental control mechanisms in two different types of families; patriarchal and egalitarian to explain the differences in self-reported male and female misconduct. In patriarchal families, traditional gender roles were in practice, where the father would work outside the home, and the mother would be responsible for the child rearing. In egalitarian families, the household roles were shared equally between mothers and fathers.<ref>O'Grady 2007, p. 110.</ref>
The theory was originally posited by [[John Hagan (sociologist)|John Hagan]] and further developed by [[A. R. Gillis]] and [[John Simpson (sociologist)|John Simpson]] at the [[University of Toronto]].<ref name="clarify and extend">{{Cite journal|last1=Hagan|first1=John |first2=A. R. |last2=Gillis |first3=John |last3=Simpson|date=January 1990|title=Clarifiying and Extending Power-Control Theory|journal=The American Journal of Sociology|publisher=University of Toronto|volume= 95|issue= 4|pages=1024–1037|jstor=2780649|doi=10.1086/229384}}</ref>
==Development==
The power control theory was developed through a series of self-report surveys that was administered to high school students and their parents in suburban Toronto. Hagan and his colleagues contended that gender and the social class of the students' parents affected how much freedom these students had. For example, coming of age as they argued, was a more limiting experience than growing up as a male. Thereby, they found that the amount of power a parent had in the workplace was related to the control displayed in the household over their teenaged children. Moreover, parents who had the types of jobs where they must supervise the activities of subordinates also tended to be relatively tolerant of the trouble-making behaviour of their children, especially of their sons. This meant that teenaged boys are freer to deviate than teenaged girls. This study also found, focusing on relatively minor forms of deviance such as shoplifting and breaking street lights, that middle-class youth actually were freer to deviate than working-class youth.<ref name="O'Grady 2007, p. 111">O'Grady 2007, p. 111.</ref>
==Limitations==
According to Julian Tanner, he offers two interesting critical comments. Though the power control theory effectively explains common delinquency among ordinary youth, it does not explain violent and repetitive crime and, therefore, the power control theory cannot predict such behavior. In addition, the power control theory suggests that parents in egalitarian households are more likely to raise females as delinquent than a female growing up in a patriarchal family; however, UCR (uniform crime report) data shows that the opposite association exists and that the involvement in female labor force is actually related to lower levels of female delinquency. Also, after years of refining the power control theory, theorists have found the notion that mothers being more controlling over their daughters are more likely to be found in egalitarian families than patriarchal families, which is the opposite relationship the power control theory would likely predict.
When the theory was refined over the years, Singer and Levine (1988) found mixed support for the theory in their early attempts to test this theory. While mothers were seen to be more controlling over their daughters than their sons, the authors also found this to be more so with egalitarian than patriarchal families, which is a finding opposite to what power control theory would predict.<ref name="O'Grady 2007, p. 111"/>
==Theory extended beyond family==
The theory has been extended into adult social roles as well. Stratified behaviors typically associated with males, particularly those in authoritative positions, are now being seen more frequently in females attaining powerful roles. And like their male counterparts, their power is used to control those persons in subordinate roles, as indicated by the rise in reports of sexual harassment (cougar syndrome) and cronyism.
Despite the explanation of social roles, there has not been a feminist theory that is fully developed to explain for the uniqueness of female criminality. While males are reported to be more involved in every type of crime, females tend to be arrested for considerably minor property crimes. This is due to the idea that the character and level of female crime is not consistent with the traditional sociological explanations of crime.<ref>O'Grady 2007, p. 112.</ref>
==References==
{{Reflist}} *O'Grady, William (2007). ''Crime in Canadian Context'', Oxford University Press, p. 110-112.
==Further reading==

==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100306053448/http://www.apsu.edu/oconnort/crim/crimtheory15.htm Conflict Criminology], Austin Peay State University * [http://sociologyindex.com/power_control_theory.htm POWER-CONTROL THEORY], Sociology Index

{{Refimprove|date=July 2010}} '''Precision bias''' is a form of [[cognitive bias]] in which an evaluator of information commits a logical [[fallacy]] as the result of confusing [[accuracy and precision]]. More particularly, in assessing the merits of an argument, a measurement, or a report, an observer or assessor falls prey to precision bias when he or she believes that greater precision implies greater accuracy (i.e., that simply because a statement is precise, it is also true); the observer or assessor are said to provide [[false precision]].
Precision bias, whether called by that phrase or another, is addressed in fields such as economics, in which there is a significant danger that a seemingly impressive quantity of statistics may be collected even though these statistics may be of little value for demonstrating any particular truth.
It is also called the numeracy bias, or the range estimate aversion.
The [[clustering illusion]] and the [[Texas sharpshooter fallacy]] may both be treated as relatives of precision bias. In these former fallacies, precision is mistakenly considered evidence of causation, when in fact the clustered information may actually be the result of [[randomness]].
==See also== *[[Accuracy and precision]]
==External links== * [http://www.e-elgar.co.uk/bookentry_main.lasso?id=307 ''Truth Versus Precision In Economics'', Thomas Mayer, Emeritus Professor of Economics, University of California] * [https://www.onepetro.org/conference-paper/PSIG-0009 "Less Is More: Accuracy vs. Precision In Modeling", Susan Bachman et al.] ("Many modelers assume that building with more precision yields a more accurate model.")
